description: From Middle English passen, from Old French passer (“to step, walk, pass”), from Vulgar Latin *passāre (“step, walk, pass”), derived from Latin passus (“a step”), from pandere (“spread, unfold, stretch”), from Proto-Italic *patnō, from Proto-Indo-European *pth₂noh₂, from Proto-Indo-European *peth₂- (“to spread, stretch out”). Cognate with Old English fæþm (“armful, fathom”). More at fathom.

verbs.description: pass (third-person singular simple present passes, present participle passing, simple past and past participle passed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move or be moved from one place to another.
examples: They passed from room to room.
Synonyms: go, move

entries.meaning: (transitive) To go past, by, over, or through; to proceed from one side to the other of; to move past.
examples: Synonyms: overtake, pass by, pass over
You will pass a house on your right.

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To cause to move or go; to send; to transfer from one person, place, or condition to another.
examples: Synonyms: deliver, give, hand, make over, send, transfer, transmit
The waiter passed biscuits and cheese.
John passed Suzie a note.
The torch was passed from hand to hand.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive, medicine) To eliminate (something) from the body by natural processes.
examples: Synonyms: evacuate, void
He was passing blood in both his urine and his stool.
The poison had been passed by the time of the autopsy.

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To take a turn with (a line, gasket, etc.), as around a sail in furling, and make secure.
(sports) To make various kinds of movement.
examples: Iaquinta passes it coolly into the right-hand corner as Paston dives the other way.

entries.meaning: (transitive, soccer) To kick (the ball) with precision rather than at full force.
examples: Iaquinta passes it coolly into the right-hand corner as Paston dives the other way.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move (the ball or puck) to a teammate.
(intransitive, fencing) To make a lunge or swipe.
examples: Synonym: thrust

entries.meaning: (intransitive, American football) To throw the ball, generally downfield, towards a teammate.
examples: The Patriots passed on third and long.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go from one person to another.
(transitive) To put in circulation; to give currency to.
examples: Synonyms: circulate, pass around
pass counterfeit money

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to obtain entrance, admission, or conveyance.
examples: Synonyms: admit, let in, let past
pass a person into a theater or over a railroad

entries.meaning: (transitive, cooking) To put through a sieve.
examples: When it's finished cooking, you should pass the sauce to get rid of any lumps.

definitionGroups.group: To change in state or status

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To progress from one state to another; to advance.
examples: He passed from youth into old age.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To depart, to cease, to come to an end.
examples: At first, she was worried, but that feeling soon passed.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To die.
examples: Synonyms: pass away, pass on, pass over; see also Thesaurus:die
His grandmother passed yesterday.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To achieve a successful outcome from.
examples: He attempted the examination, but did not expect to pass.
Of the Ancient Wonders, only the pyramids have passed the test of time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To advance through all the steps or stages necessary to become valid or effective; to obtain the formal sanction of (a legislative body).
examples: Synonym: be accepted by
Despite the efforts of the opposition, the bill passed.
The bill passed both houses of Congress.
The bill passed the Senate, but did not pass in the House.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, law) To be conveyed or transferred by will, deed, or other instrument of conveyance.
examples: The estate passes by the third clause in Mr Smith's deed to his son.
When the old king passed away with only a daughter as an heir, the throne passed to a woman for the first time in centuries.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to advance by stages of progress; to carry on with success through an ordeal, examination, or action; specifically, to give legal or official sanction to; to ratify; to enact; to approve as valid and just.
examples: Synonyms: approve, enact, ratify
He passed the bill through the committee.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, law) To make a judgment on or upon a person or case.
examples: And within three dayes twelve knyghtes passed uppon hem; and they founde Sir Palomydes gylty, and Sir Saphir nat gylty, of the lordis deth.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter; to pronounce; to pledge.
examples: Synonyms: pronounce, say, speak, utter

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change from one state to another (without the implication of progression).
(intransitive, of time) To elapse, to be spent.
examples: Synonyms: elapse, go by; see also Thesaurus:elapse
Their vacation passed pleasantly.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of time) To spend.
examples: What will we do to pass the time?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To go by without noticing; to omit attention to; to take no note of; to disregard.
examples: Synonyms: disregard, ignore, take no notice of; see also Thesaurus:ignore

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To continue.
examples: Synonyms: continue, go on

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To proceed without hindrance or opposition.
examples: You're late, but I'll let it pass.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To live through; to have experience of; to undergo; to suffer.
examples: Synonyms: bear, endure, suffer, tolerate, undergo; see also Thesaurus:tolerate

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To happen.
examples: Synonyms: happen, occur; see also Thesaurus:happen
It will soon come to pass.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, stative) To be tolerated as a substitute for something else, to "do".
examples: It isn't ideal, but it will pass.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, stative, sociology) To be accepted by others as a member of a race, sex, or other group to which one does not belong or would not have originally appeared to belong; especially to be considered white although one has black ancestry, or a woman although one was assigned male at birth or vice versa.
(intransitive) To decline something that is offered or available.
examples: Coordinate terms: pass on, pass up
He asked me to go to the cinema with him, but I think I'll pass.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reject; to pass up.
examples: Instead, the board voted to suspend the dividend, giving Orton his way at last. They passed the dividend again in June 1870  […]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To decline or not attempt to answer a question.
examples: I haven't any idea of the answer, so I'll have to pass.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) In turn-based games, to decline to play in one's turn.
(intransitive, card games) In euchre, to decline to make the trump.
(intransitive, obsolete) To go beyond bounds; to surpass; to be in excess.
examples: Synonyms: exceed, surpass

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transcend; to surpass; to excel; to exceed.
examples: Synonyms: better, exceed, excel, outdo, surpass, transcend; see also Thesaurus:exceed

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To take heed, to have an interest, to care.
examples: Synonyms: take heed, take notice; see also Thesaurus:pay attention

description: From Middle English pas, pase, pace, from passen (“to pass”).

entries.meaning: An opening, road, or track, available for passing; especially, one through or over some dangerous or otherwise impracticable barrier such as a mountain range; a passageway; a defile; a ford.
examples: Synonyms: gap, notch
mountain pass

entries.meaning: A channel connecting a river or body of water to the sea, for example at the mouth (delta) of a river.
examples: the passes of the Mississippi

entries.meaning: A single movement, especially of a hand, at, over, or along anything.
examples: [The bear] made a pass at the dog, but he swung out and above him  […]

entries.meaning: A single passage of a tool over something, or of something over a tool.
examples: Synonym: transit

entries.meaning: An attempt.
examples: My first pass at a career of writing proved unsuccessful.

entries.meaning: Success in an examination or similar test.
examples: I gained three passes at A-level, in mathematics, French, and English literature.

entries.meaning: (fencing) A thrust or push; an attempt to stab or strike an adversary.
examples: Synonym: thrust

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A thrust; a sally of wit.
A sexual advance.
examples: Synonyms: proposition, come on, hit on
The man kicked his friend out of the house after he made a pass at his wife.

entries.meaning: (sports) The act of moving the ball or puck from one player to another.
(rail transport) A passing of two trains in the same direction on a single track, when one is put into a siding to let the other overtake it.
examples: Antonym: meet

entries.meaning: Permission or license to pass, or to go and come.
examples: A ship sailing under the flag and pass of an enemy.

entries.meaning: A document granting permission to pass or to go and come; a passport; a ticket permitting free transit or admission
examples: a railroad pass; a theater pass; a military pass

entries.meaning: (baseball) An intentional walk.
examples: Smith was given a pass after Jones' double.

entries.meaning: (sports) The act of overtaking; an overtaking manoeuvre.
The state of things; condition; predicament; impasse.
examples: Synonyms: condition, predicament, state

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Estimation; character.
(cooking) The area in a restaurant kitchen where the finished dishes are passed from the chefs to the waiting staff.
An act of declining to play one's turn in a game, often by saying the word "pass".
examples: A pass would have seen her win the game, but instead she gave a wrong answer and lost a point, putting her in second place.

entries.meaning: (computing) A run through a document as part of a translation, compilation or reformatting process.
examples: Most Pascal compilers process source code in a single pass.

entries.meaning: (computing, slang) A password (especially one for a restricted-access website).
examples: Anyone want to trade passes?
